headline: Oven Pot Roast
description: This pot roast recipe made in the oven is browned in butter and baked in a delicious gravy of mushroom soup and vermouth for an easy weeknight dinner.

video.description: See how to make a simple pot roast baked with mushroom soup and vermouth.
video.name: Oven Pot Roast

name: Oven Pot Roast
recipeIngredient: 1 (10.5 ounce) can condensed cream of mushroom soup
0.5 (1 ounce) envelope dry onion soup mix

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).
Combine flour and black pepper in a large bowl. Dredge rump roast in seasoned flour and cover evenly. Shake off excess.
Melt butter in a large pot over medium-high heat. Brown roast in melted butter on all sides. Place in a 4-quart casserole dish with lid.
Combine condensed soup, vermouth, and soup mix in a small bowl; pour over roast.
Cover and bake in the preheated oven until desired doneness, about 3 hours. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 145 degrees F (63 degrees C) for medium doneness.

review.reviewBody: I never use chuck for anything but burgers and meatballs. Rump is and always will be the only cut of beef for pot roast. Followed the recipe exactly and it turned out perfect. No more boiling. I'll get a picture next time. Allrecipes is my go to site for great ideas when I want to try something new and different.

I have made hundreds of pot roast. This was the best of all of them. The cream of mushroom soup makes a gravy that is absolutely incredible. I served it over Jasmine rice.....soooo Good!!! The best recipe yet!!!
Really enjoyed this recipe for pot roast. Very easy and the gravy was delicious.

This recipe is fantastic! Best roast I ever made. I did not have the wine, so I added 1.5 cans of beef broth. I did add my own seasonings (season salt and garlic powder) to the roast before coating it with flour to brown it. I used a whole packet of soup mix. It was tender and delicious! This is a keeper.
Delicious gravy. I used a 2-1/2 lb. inside blade roast. So tender and not stringy. Plenty for 5 people.

The BEST roast ever! So very very good. I did sautee onions with it while I was browning the meat in a Cast Iron skillet. I kept it in the skillet when cooking it in the oven. Perfect cooking time and temperature at 325.
Very Good. I did not any Lipton soup mix so I substituted a can of Campbells Beefy Mushroom soup. All else was the same.

This came out AMAZING! I tweaked it a little bit though…instead of white wine or vermouth, I used a homemade spiced Riesling. I also deglazed my pan with the spiced Riesling and used that over the toast as well. Gives it a wonderful German-flair taste! Served it with smashed potatoes and green beans!

I’ve been looking for the perfect pot roast recipe for a while. All the crockpot ones I made seemed to be lacking something or the meat tasted too overdone despite following exact directions. THIS was amazing. I didn’t alter it at all, but did throw in carrots, some small potatoes and one onion the last hour as someone else had recommended. My new go to pot roast recipe!

I added my own yumminess to this such as tripling the cream of mushroom soup & adding cream of celery soup. Used red wine & tenderized the meat with tenderizer & worstcheshire sauce for about 2 & 1/2 hours beforehand. I added garlic powder, garlic pepper, & Uncle CHRIS steak seasoning to the dry mixture too. We like a lot of gravy so it came out perfect!
This recipe makes an awesome pot roast. The beef is tender & flavorful; the gravy so good. I did not have vermouth, so I substituted a dry red wine. So good!

Omg. This is the best pot roast recipe ever. So tender. This recipe is a keeper. Next time i’ll use a teeny bit less butter because i dont think it needs 1/4 cup and wont really alter the flavour too much.

I used white wine vinegar instead of vermouth. So I used 1 envelope of onion soup, 2 cans of cream of mushrooms and 
1 1/2 cups of white wine vinegar. It was too thick that’s why I added more white wine vinegar. Will let you know later how good it was.

Very good. I made a half batch for just my husband and myself. Used the leftover 'glaze' to make gravy. Put carrots in at the last 75 minutes of cooking. Perfect. Not mushy. Made in my Pampered Chef Stone Dutch Oven. Very yummy.

Rave reviews from friends over this ultimate comfort food; it started us reminiscing about our favorite dishes that mom used to make. As others suggested, I turned the temp down and cooked a little longer, and added potatoes, carrots and rutabaga during the last hour of cooking. I cooked at 300 for about 4 hours.
My 3rd time using this recipe and it is always perfect. Tried other recipes. This is still my go to its the best.

Omg...this was outstanding. 

I prepared the roast in flour and seared in butter. Then I declared the pan with the wine. I only had white cooking wine so I used that.

Then I stirred in the onion soup mix and cream of mushroom soup in the pan and poured that over the roast.

I used foil then baked at 275 for 3 hours...I added my veggies the last hour and they were perfect. 

The gravy is so good...this is my new roast recipe for sure.

Fabulous. Three bites in my husband asked me to make this again next week. I had a 2.75 lb eye of round. I mixed Montreal seasoning with the flour. I browned it in butter but the butter burned so I drained the pot after browning. I added the wine to the pot and then the onion soup mix, the mushroom soup, a cup of water with a tsp of beef Better than Bullion, a tsp each of Worcestershire and horseradish. Added the beef and spooned the sauce over the meat. I cooked it at 300* for 3 and a half hours. I added quartered Yukon gold potatoes and carrots at the 2 hour mark. I’ve been making pot roast for 50 years. This is number one!

Delicious!! I followed the recipe plus the most common tweaks suggested by other reviewers, and the roast turned out perfectly seasoned and very tender! The gravy was super-savory-delish, served on top of garlic smashed potatoes, and our side was sautéed spinach, grape tomatoes and garlic. A fantastic dinner! Thanks for the great recipe!
This is a keeper for sure! The aroma in the house, while cooking was killing us! in the best way!!
Wow!!! Just wow!!

Beautiful and delicious! I would double the gravy ingredients next time as I served it over noodles for something different. Very good and I could use products without MSG as alternatives to what was listed.
This is my new go-to pot roast. I followed others and placed carrots in the last hour. That makes them perfect

This was the best pot roast ever! My husband was crazy for it. I did use the suggestion of seasoned salt & garlic powder, plus I used the entire envelope of onion soup mix. Abit more wine too than recipe listed. Added carrots & potatoes during the last hour. Will definitely make again! Thank you for the recipe.

Literally the best roast I’ve ever made. Just outstanding. I don’t drink, so I didn’t have white wine on hand. Instead I used balsamic to deglaze the pan after browning the meat. I also didn’t have mushroom soup so I used cream of chicken (couldn’t taste the chicken so it was a win!). It was so tasty and it made the best gravy for mashed potatoes. I’ll definitely be making this again!!

Made exactly as posted except doubled the recipe as we like leftovers and added some seasoned salt and garlic powder per other suggestions. It was delicious! I threw in potatoes and carrots for the last hour and 15 minutes. My teens loved it and 17 year old even said “I’m having this for breakfast!”
Substituted red wine, instead of Vermouth. And Venison roast, instead of beef.

First time making a pot roast of any sort and oh my this was amazing. I added more seasoning to the flour mix, adobo, garlic, paprika and pepper. Came out perfect after three hours and 15 mins absolutely delicious!
I used the consommé as suggested in the comments. I also used umami spice that I got at trader Joe’s. The taste was fantastic and even better the next day.

Served this for Christmas dinner to a crowd of 15 and everyone kept saying it was wonderful. I used 2 roasts for a total of 5.5# and because I'm Gluten Free and Dairy Free I made a few changes. I subbed olive oil for the butter and made my own onion soup mix from this site. For the cream of mushroom soup, I sliced mushrooms and mixed that with the remaining flour/pepper mixture. Dumped that on top of the roast and poured 2 cups of beef broth around the sides and a heavy cup of red wine. I did add a big tablespoon of diced garlic on top of the meat. Cooked in a turkey roaster 350° for about 3-1/2 hours turning over once.
The only thing I changed is I did it in my Ninja Slowcooker for 6 hours...3 hours on high and 3 hours on low. It was really good.

Excellent recipe. I used chuck instead of rump roast and added potatoes and carrots cut into 1 1/2" chunks. The slow simmer time makes everything tastes so good. I used a whole packet of onion soup mix. The potatoes take out the saltiness of the soup mix. I use red white instead of vermouth.

This was everything the reviews said it was - easy, fast into the oven, and DELICIOUS. They could sell Febreze in this scent- made the whole house smell cozy! I browned it in a Le Creuset French oven, scraped the bits loose with a can of beef consommé, dumped the combined dry vermouth and soups over, slapped the lid on and that was all she wrote...added quartered carrots, potatoes and a Maui onion and YUM.

I've made this many times and it always gets rave reviews from guests. It is one of my favorite recipes when I have guests coming over. A dutch oven makes it really easy and there is very little cleanup. Just cook any vegetables separately.

I had to substitute cream of chicken soup and red wine, but it came out absolutely awesome. I was out of mushroom soup, and cream of chicken was all I had. I used the whole can, then filled the can with red wine, and mixed the whole thing up with one packet of onion soup mix. And as promised, it smelled heavenly while it was in the oven.
I made this exactly as written and my search for the perfect pot roast is over! I’ve made many pot roasts that were more complicated and didn’t turn out as delicious as this.

Pretty good, and used up some onion soup mix and vermouth that I was wanting to use up. Also put potatoes and carrots in. Makes lots of gravy; the gravy is sort of a lighter brown gravy from the cream of mushroom soup.
Wonderful, easy recipe. My family loves it!
Excellent!
Excellent!
SCRUMPTIOUS DELIOUSE! !! I USED ORIGINAL RECIPE!!!
Delicious! Everyone loved it and ate every last bite! I added 2 teaspoons of liquid smoke on a whim and couldn't believe how much flavor it added.
Turned out wonderfully flavorful & tender. Definitely a keeper.
Great recipe. My family loved it! An added bonus is the wonderful smell while it's cooking.
Added quartered potatoes and carrots (added in the last 1-1.5 hrs) but otherwise followed the receipe exactly and it was perfect.
Followed the directions to the letter flavor was good but even though my roast was just a bit over LB wise it was very very over cooked.

Best pot roast I've ever eaten. Everyone I serve this to say so as well. It is sooooo easy too.I make this with eye round roasts. They are my favorite beef roasts. I mix up the seasonings. Sometimes onion soup mix, sometimes season all salt. Great both ways. And I sub the alcohol with Kitchen Basics vegetable stock.
This was delicious. I did not have vermouth so used Sangria. The “gravy” was great. The meat pretty much fell apart and melted in your mouth. Will definitely make again.

I made this recipe tonight, the only change was I didn't have dry Vermouth so I used a Riesling wine! I can't tell you how grateful I am for this recipe, it was absolutely delicious and so easy! Not a ton of ingredients but the flavor was outstanding! The gravy that it made was unbelievable, doused it over my boiled red potatoes! The meat fell apart, and cooked perfectly! Thank you so much for a great recipe!

This is so good ~ I recommend using a meat thermometer as it was done before 3 hours and all ovens vary. I added the whole package of dry onion soup and whole can of beef Consommé instead of vermouth, makes great gravy to put over everything you put into the pot.
Excellent. Whole family loved it. I did add beef broth instead of wine. Made a wonderful gravy.
Crowd pleaser! Didn’t have vermouth (don’t even know what that is) just used wine and water instead and it was delish. I also only used half the package of onion soup mix. Baked at 325 for 3 hours.
Fabulous! I cooked the roast for an hour and 1/2 then added potatoes and carrots and baked for one more hour. Perfect!
This was so easy. Didn’t have the Vermouth so I used white wine. I also read the second review and added garden vegetable broth (it’s all I had) for more gravy. Delish!

I’ve had close to this same recipe for years. And, truth be told, it’s the best pot roast ever. I add sour cream for the last hour of roasting and then I have sour cream gravy. I always make mashed potatoes as I don’t like everything to taste the same. And, that gravy on the roast and mashed potatoes is to die for. I mince garlic and sauté it in my Dutch Oven before I brown the roast. Stove to oven. Then back up to stove to make the gravy. Delicious.

Perfect!! I did as another reviewer recommended and cooked it for 5 hours on 250. Put carrots, onions and potatoes in for the last 2 hours. I also added another can of cream of mushroom and Lipton onion soup mix when I put in the veggies.
I used a 3-lb. boneless chuck roast, Golden Mushroom Soup and sweet vermouth because that’s what I had. It made wonderful gravy (after I slimmed
I used chuck steak that I cut in big pieces and browned. I also used cream of celery soup which took away the metallic taste. I make it often as the family loves it and there’s never any leftovers.
Really solid pot roast. I used a pot roast instead of a rump roast. And I pulled it after two hours. Very flavorful
Will be making this again. Followed recipe as directed

I gave it 5 stars this turned out so good and simple to make! I always have a stock pile of cream of mushroom soup and wouldn’t you know I ran out! I ended up using cream of celery and it turned out just fine! I also added some potatoes and carrots because we love having that with our pot roast. Great simple recipe and will be making this again in the future.

Delicious! I used beef broth instead of wine. I also cooked it slow as others have said, 275 Convection for about 5 hours. I added vegetables the last 2 hours, the last part without the lid on to brown them up. Will be making this again!
I made it it was a savory dinner that night. Even the peky eaters ate seconds. These recipe is a keeper

Omg was this good! I opted to use a chuck roast which revealed a tender, moist roast. I added quartered onion, baby carrots and celery chunks the last hour of cooking. I used white wine instead of vermouth. So good! Definitely a “do-over”!

Delicious! This is definitely a keeper and I will be making this again.
I did add some garlic powder, paprika, and cayenne to the flour. And because I seared it in a dutch oven, I deglazed the pan with a bit of white wine.

I used Whole Foods organic cream of mushroom soup , substituting Trader Joe’s Onion Salt blend for the onion soup mix, and 1/2- 3/4 cup red wine, also a little water. I then followed the recipe. It was delicious. I usually use my crockpot but it came out so much better in the oven.
This so so EASY and more importantly so GOOD!
Great recipe. This is my "go to" recipe when I take a meal to someone who is ill. I've been told, the gravy is so good, you want to drink it with a straw.

I’m usually not a fan of rump roast, but this recipe nailed it! I started with a roast that was previously frozen (as we buy 1/2 steer every year), made sure my roast was thawed and followed the recipe exactly. We’ll expect for using Lipton Recipe Secrets Savory Herb with Garlic instead of the onion soup mix. The roas was very good and tender. I would certainly do this again.
Excellent recipe! Like other users, I added my veggies in the last hour of cooking, and I also added a cup of beef broth with a little flour to make more gravy.
Replaced vermouth with water, it tasted great!
Instead of vermouth or wine I substituted 1C beef bouillon. Delicious!

It was a huge hit with a large crowd - I actually made 2 large chuck roasts at the same time so I had to use extra large cans of mushroom soup. Didn't have vermouth (which I REALLY wanted to try in the recipe but no time to get it). So I had to resort to white cooking wine - I know, I know BUT...it was fantastic. I've made the basics of this recipe before I found this one that inspired adding the wine (since no vermouth). Using it next time! I've used red wine in mine before but liked this better. I upped all gravy ingredients to have more and added a bit of garlic powder and sonoma pepper. Delicious. Thanks for sharing Becky!

The flavor was really one-note and it definitely did not pull apart easily as good pot roast should. In order to salvage this I added a lot of beef stock as it cooked and added rosemary and parsley near the end. I also had to force it apart and cook it in chunks because there was no flavor in the meat - probably because it is a fairly lean cut. Because this recipe looked so easy and had great reviews I decided to try it. Problem is, too many people who've reviewed it gave it higher rating because of the changes they made to the recipe.

I made this and it was great. I modified hings slightly by adding red potatoes, carrots and celery (as well as an extra half cup of white wine). The mushroom/onion soup/wine broth served as an excellent gravy right out of the pan.
Easy, delicious, a must try!
The best pot roast I've ever had! We cooked it exactly as the recipe states but added carrots, red potato, and celery half way through. It was amazing!
I slow cooked this is my cast iron Dutch oven. It was AMAZING! Added cubed red potatoes, baby carrots, and some beach mushrooms an hour before finished. The gravy is divine!
Outstanding!

Delicious!! Changed a few things: used beef stock in place of the wine.. put garlic paprika and pepper in the flour added ref potatoes a big sweet onion and carrots and baked it at 275f for 4 1/2 hours(coulda prolly been done at 4 hours
It was very easy and my family really liked it. I used white wine vinegar instead of vermouth. The vinegar taste was a little strong for me. I will try vermouth next time.
Followed the recipe exactly. It was delicious and even better the next day!
Delicious - absolutely loved it! I used a Chuck Roast instead of Rump.

This was delicious and very tender! I used white wine vs sherry, just because that's what I had on-hand. My husband doesn't like cream of mushroom soup in recipes so I substituted two cans of beef stock (two to make sure there was enough gravy). I'll make it again!

FINALLY! A 5 Star recipe that ACTUALLY DESERVES 5 stars!! I'm so sick of making 5 star recipes only to wonder if I'm from another planet! I made this AS IS (except I used a whole soup packet by pure accident instead of 1/2) and it was wonderful, my husband nearly licked his plate. 

A 5 star recipe should be COMPANY WORTHY, & THIS IS!!! Thank you Becky!

This is a tried and true recipe. I've used English cut, chuck roast, rump roast and sirloin tip for this recipe. It has never failed to be very tender and juicy. Only change, double the gravy ingredients.

I double the recipe for the "sauce" and then mix it with cut up yellow or red potatoes, sliced sweet yellow onion and baby carrots. I fill a cast-iron dutch iron with the pot roast on the bottom and veggies all around. This has to cook at the same temperature, but for four hours. The pot roast is falling apart and the veggies delicious. It feeds the three of us for at least two meals or more. Love this recipe. My modifications occurred over making at least a half of dozen times.

Wow! Talk about a classic yummy pot roast! this is now going to be my go-to roast recipe. I did do a few things differently since I didn't have some of the ingredients. I used cream of chicken (I know, but it was all I had!), and white wine instead of vermouth. My roast was only two pounds and I was in a hurry so I cooked it in a Dutch oven at 375 degrees for 1 hour. I will cook it longer next time so it will be more tender. The gravy was to die for! Next time I will put more potatoes in the pot so I can eat more of the gravy!
It turned out very well. It is a keeper!

I made this tonight for my family - a group of 7 adults. My boys were skeptical because I've had lots of roast "fails" and I didn't check the reviews first! To my surprise, I found vermouth in the house! Hubby doesn't do mushrooms, so I doubled the sauce for 2 roasts - using one can of cream of chicken and one cream of celery. otherwise, I pretty much followed the recipe. Used a roaster on the burner to brown the roasts and popped them in the oven. I flipped them over every 45 minutes or so, to keep it all juicy. Amazing aroma! I kept them in the oven for 4 hours - just because there were 2 roasts. Everyone loved it and went back for seconds! And they wanted to know what I did differently! Thank you! This will be a repeat favorite for us!
Great recipe! I use beef broth in place of vermouth & I double the amount. I also cook at 350 & add in potatoes & carrots the last hour
Easy to make and very good!
Best pot roast known to man.

Loved this recipe. I combined this recipe with another. Followed same instructions, only I cut the meat in 1-2 inch pieces & dredged in flour. In a large pan, add 2 TBSP oil & sear the chunks of meat until brown. Remove from pan & set meat aside. Mushroom Mixture: Reduce heat to medium. In same large pan, add 1/4 cup butter, saute 8 oz. of sliced mushrooms, 1 med. chopped onion & 2 chopped garlic cloves. Cook 5 mins. Stir 1 1/2 tsp flour, cook & stir 1 minute. In a small bowl, combine the Cream of Celery, Onion soup mix & 1/2 cup White Wine. Add to Mushroom Mixture in pan & add broth as needed. Simmer 10 minutes. Pour over Roast in large skillet. Bake up to 3 hours. In last 2 hours of baking, add 5 med carrots cut into chunks & 5 small Golden Yukon potatoes cut into quarter size. Add broth as needed for a gravy mixture. Enjoy : ) Sarasmiles
This was really easy to make and delicious. The meat was tender and the juices made a great gravy. I saved this in my recipes.
Best beef gravy ever!

Made this for Christmas dinner for the people who don't like Italian food. They loved it! I followed a combination of reviewers, one who spiced up the dredging flour and one who suggested mushroom gravy powder instead of the onion soup mix. Everyone around the table loved it, and I will totally be making this again.
Great recipe. Added whole mini potatoes, 4 shallots and carrots.
Very good easy to make
